titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Cooperative League of New York Photographs PHOTOS.138

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-03-07T13:21-0500

change.item: Edited by Mary Corcoran for compliance with DACS and Tamiment Required Elements for Archival Description

did.unittitle: Cooperative League of New York Photographs

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

did.abstract: The Cooperative League of New York is a chapter of the reformist socialist organization,The Cooperative League of America, established by James Peter Warbasse in 1916.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Cooperative League of New York; PHOTOS 138; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The Cooperative League of New York Photographs is composed of five 8x10 glass plate negatives documenting the Cooperative League's hat store.

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Cooperative League of New York Photographs document The Cooperative League of New York's hat store.

processinfo.head: Processing Information Note
processinfo.p: The Cooperative League of New York Photographs were rehoused in a shared box in February 2013.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use Note
accessrestrict.p:
Copyright status unknown.
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2630
Fax: (212) 995-4225
E-mail: tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu

custodhist.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
custodhist.p: The Cooperative League of New York Photographs were donated by Verna Rudd Kenvin on August 12th, 1986.

arrangement.head: Arrangement Note
arrangement.p: Materials have been arranged by an archivist within a single folder.
